Flesh curvature; the subtle curve in a blade's thickness distribution creating dimensional depth.
The distribution of thickness/meat across the blade, indicating robustness.
Extremely fine martensite particles not individually visible, creating a misty, cloud-like appearance along the hamon.
Made predominantly of nioi; a soft, misty hamon appearance.
Nioi-dominant; more nioi than nie in the hamon.
The visible edge of the hamon where hardened steel meets softer steel.
Brocade wrapping; decorative silk fabric covering used on sword fittings or storage.
Two-piece set, typically referring to matching kozuka and kogai fittings.
Imitation or fake item; a reproduction made to resemble an authentic piece.
Norisada; refers to smiths or works associated with this name lineage.
The feeling or appearance of extension; refers to graceful elongation in blade proportions.
Rising grain; steel grain pattern that appears to flow upward along the blade.
To extend or stretch; may refer to elongated proportions in blade geometry or fittings design.
A Yamashiro school active from late Kamakura into Muromachi, often showing Soshu influence.
Extra-long tachi sword, typically over 3 shaku (90cm), used ceremonially or by foot soldiers.
Decorative motif resembling dried abalone strips, symbolizing good fortune in Japanese art.
Gentle, wave-like undulations in the hamon.
Undulating temper line; a hamon with gentle, wave-like curves along the cutting edge.
A subtle undulating quality in the hamon; having the spirit or essence of notare patterning.
Notare with clove pattern; wavy hamon combined with regular semi-circular gunome formations.
Waves that extend deeply into the blade.
Irregular notare; wavy hamon pattern with additional random undulations and variations.
Nihon Token Hozon Kai (Japan Sword Preservation Society); a sword authentication organization issuing certificates including Kanteisho grades.
Gap, void, or missing element; absence of expected feature or component.
Cloth-pattern inlay; metal pressed into cross-hatched surface.
Wet appearance; describes a lustrous, moist-looking surface quality on the blade.
Wet appearance; describes areas of the hamon or hada with a moist, dark quality.
Wet application technique in lacquerwork where successive layers are applied before the previous layer fully dries.
Wet blade appearance; a hamon with a moist, glossy quality that appears to glisten like wet steel.
A type of hamon where the temper line appears to 'wet' or soak into the steel with soft, blurred edges.
Wet appearance; lustrous, moist-looking surface quality in the steel or hamon.
Major rise or significant upward curve, often describing dramatic blade geometry changes.
Large jaw or chin; refers to a prominent curved feature on blade geometry.
Large clove pattern.
Large irregular clove pattern; bold, varied chōji formations in the hamon.
Great sword; an extra-large tachi, typically over 90cm, used ceremonially or by cavalry.
Large gunome pattern.
Large irregular gunome pattern; a hamon with prominent, irregularly spaced clove-shaped formations.
Large grain pattern; coarse, prominent steel grain texture visible on the blade.
Large flat construction; wide blade profile without ridge line (shinogi).
Great master carving; high-quality horimono executed by renowned artisans.
Large, coarse wood-grain pattern.
Large wood-grain pattern; a coarse, prominent itame grain texture in the steel.
A large, extended point, characteristic of Nanbokucho period blades.
Large, rounded turn-back.
Large irregular pattern.
Large, coarse burl-grain pattern.
Large, pronounced wave pattern.
Large point; refers to a blade with an extended or prominent kissaki (point) area.
Large tip cut; describes a blade with significant shortening at the point end.
Large angled cut at the tang tip; a specific style of nakago-jiri termination.
Large spacer washer placed between tsuba and tsuka on a mounted sword.
Steeply angled diagonal file marks.
Greatly shortened; tang significantly reduced in length, typically resulting in loss of the original signature (mei).
A Japanese era period (1368-1375); often referenced in sword dating and historical classification.
Large size or format; refers to oversized proportions in blades, fittings, or decorative elements.
Belt fastening; a cord or tie used to secure an obi sash or similar binding.
Belt attachment or sword suspension method; refers to wearing arrangement of mounted blades.
Hazy silver; a muted silver finish or patina with a cloudy, subdued appearance.
Hazy silver; a muted silver alloy used in sword fittings with a subdued, cloudy appearance.
Large or oversized proportions; refers to blades with generous dimensions.
Large clustered clove pattern; chōji hamon with prominently sized formations.
Extra-long tachi, typically over 3 shaku (90cm), often ceremonial or votive pieces.
Gentle, calm, or subdued appearance; restrained and peaceful aesthetic quality.
Large bell; bell-shaped form or decoration found in sword fittings and ornaments.
Large flat construction; blade geometry with wide, flat surfaces and minimal ridgeline.
Placed metal; decorative metal inlay or overlay applied to surfaces.
A type of file mark pattern on the nakago resembling the wrinkled face of an old man.
Raised rim or edge detail on tsuba or other sword fittings.
A Yamato school associated with Omiya shrine. Includes Morikuni and later generations.
The front or outer side (facing out when worn).
Famous Kamakura period tachi by Kunitsuna; one of the Tenka-Goken legendary swords.
Certificate of authenticity; traditionally folded appraisal document, historically issued by the Hon'ami family during the Edo period.
Folded metal technique used in sword construction or decorative metalwork.
Folded-back construction method, particularly referring to the turned edge in sword mountings.
Folded-back signature; the original mei preserved when shortening.
The process of wholesale distribution or initial sale of swords from smiths to dealers.
The most prolific Bizen school, active from Kamakura through Edo. Includes sub-branches like Nagamitsu, Kagemitsu, and later generations.
High-ranking award or recognition given to exceptional sword works.
A hamon pattern that appears to push outward from the edge in rounded, bulging formations.
Rubbing or impression of a blade; paper copy showing nakago details and signatures.
Second grade or class B; a ranking designation for sword quality assessment.
Mother-of-pearl inlay technique used in decorating sword fittings and scabbards.
A major Yamashiro school in Kyoto, active from mid-Kamakura through Nanbokucho. Known for elegant nie-deki work.
Thunder pattern; geometric spiral design resembling stylized thunder or lightning motifs.
Sacred fungus motif; decorative design representing the lingzhi mushroom of immortality.
Connected grooves; multiple parallel hi (grooves) running along the blade surface.
Lotus pedestal; Buddhist lotus throne carving.
Lotus flower; decorative motif commonly used in horimono and tsuba designs.
Paired lions; decorative motif showing two lions, often in playful interaction.
Ring or circular element, often referring to decorative rings on sword fittings or stands.
Wheel treasure; a Buddhist symbol sometimes carved as horimono on sword blades.
Wax-color finish; highly polished black lacquer.
Wax-color lacquer; a high-gloss black urushi finish polished to a mirror-like sheen.
Absent or missing design elements; decorative pattern suggesting something not present.
Both or pair; indicates bilateral symmetry or refers to matching elements in sword construction or fittings.
Double compartment; a scabbard design with two separate sections or chambers.
Double-ridged construction; a blade shape with shinogi ridges on both sides of the blade.
Both sides or flanks; refers to bilateral features or mounting elements on a sword.
Dragon character or dragon-form calligraphy used in sword inscriptions and decorative elements.
Founder of the Samonji school in Chikuzen. Known for bold Soshu-influenced style with prominent nie.
Rust or corrosion on metal surfaces, particularly on sword blades and fittings.
Fixed or established; often used in context of confirmed attributions or established characteristics of a blade.
Brilliant clarity and sharpness in the hamon and overall blade appearance.
Bright, clear, and vivid; describes a well-defined hamon.
Sagami Province; a region in present-day Kanagawa Prefecture, home to the Soshu tradition.
The cord attached to the scabbard for securing to the belt.
A broken or fragmented hamon pattern, often considered a flaw in the heat treatment.
Broken or chipped blade; damage to the cutting edge or blade body.
Reverse or opposite direction; often used to describe inverted grain or pattern flow.
Reversed or slanting ashi.
Reverse clove pattern; a hamon with chōji-like formations that lean backward against the cutting edge.
Inverted clove-shaped irregular hamon pattern where the chōji forms point downward.
Reverse or upward slanting file marks on the nakago, opposite to normal direction.
Reverse hanging; describes elements that curve or extend in the opposite expected direction.
Reverse-inclined; describing features that curve or lean in the opposite direction.
Reverse spirit; an inverted or contrary quality in the blade's appearance or structure.
Reverse gunome pattern; irregular hamon with wave-like formations pointing backward.
Reverse irregular pattern; a hamon with waves or patterns flowing opposite to normal.
Reverse or inverted; describes features oriented opposite to the normal direction.
Reverse or inverted tendency; pattern elements appearing in opposite direction.
Reverse grip; holding a weapon with the blade pointing downward or backward.
Tip or point; refers to the forward end or extremity of blade features.
A tang tip shape that resembles the point of a sword blade.
A blade that has been shortened from the tip, altering the original kissaki geometry.
Chestnut-shaped tang tip; a rounded, bulbous nakago-jiri form.
Tip pinching; a defect where the blade point appears compressed or narrowed.
Point swelling; widening of the blade toward the tip, creating a fuller point section.
Tassel or cord ornament attached to the end of sword knots or sageo.
The point where the ridge line (shinogi) disappears near the tip of the blade.
The subtle transition area where the shinogi begins to fade toward the point.
Tip uncertainty; refers to questionable or problematic condition of the sword point.
The width of the blade near the point.
Senior examiner; high-ranking official responsible for authenticating and evaluating sword quality.
Cut or shortened tip; a blade that has been repointed or had its tip altered.
Pointed chestnut end; a nakago-jiri (tang end) shaped like a tapered chestnut with a sharp point.
Curvature concentrated toward the point.
Made by; indicates the maker or school attribution of a sword or fitting.
Individual style or characteristic workmanship of a particular smith or school.
Left capital; geographic designation often found in swordsmith names or signatures.
Rayskin; the textured skin used to wrap handles.
Ray skin wrapping; the rough shark or ray skin used under the cord wrap on sword handles.
A Chikuzen Province school founded by Sa. Known for Soshu-influenced work and powerful hamon.
Three flat surfaces; refers to a triangular cross-section or three-sided geometric form.
Three-layer construction method in sword forging with distinct steel compositions.
Three-cedar pattern; groups of three pointed elements.
A traditional Japanese measurement unit equal to approximately 3mm, commonly used in sword specifications.
A measurement system using three-bu increments (approximately 9mm), commonly used in sword proportions and specifications.
Third generation; indicates the third smith in a lineage to use a particular name.
An early Yamashiro school in Kyoto, legendary for Sanjo Munechika. Active in late Heian period.
Triple-layered edge pattern; hamon showing three distinct hardened zones.
Triple-pronged vajra sword; a Buddhist ritual sword carving with a three-pronged hilt.
Three-pronged vajra handle sword; ritual blade with Buddhist three-pronged thunderbolt handle design.
Three-pronged ritual sword; a Buddhist ceremonial blade with triple-pointed design.
Three-pronged ritual sword based on Buddhist vajra symbolism.
Three-pronged handle sword; a ritual blade with a vajra-style handle used in Buddhist ceremonies.
Ritual sword with three-pronged vajra handle, used in Buddhist ceremonies.
Three-pronged vajra sword; a ritual blade with Buddhist vajra symbolism featuring triple points.
Three grades; classification system ranking sword quality into upper, middle, and lower tiers.
A boshi style characteristic of three famous Osafune smiths (Nagamitsu, Kagemitsu, Sanenaga), featuring a straight temper line through the kissaki with a small turn-back.
Japanese pepper; used to describe small, granular patterns resembling pepper seeds.
Pepper things; decorative motifs featuring Japanese pepper plants or similar botanical designs.
Variant spelling of sanshōmono; reference pieces used for comparative study.
Reference pieces or comparative examples used for authentication and study purposes.
Three-layer construction method; refers to blades made with three distinct steel layers.
The three main sword mountings: kozuka, kōgai, and menuki collectively.
Three irons; construction method using three different types of steel or iron.
Rod or pole; refers to the central shaft portion of various sword components.
Monkey hand; a type of tsuba design featuring openwork resembling a monkey's paw.
Bamboo leaf spear; a type of spear with a leaf-shaped blade resembling bamboo.
Small ripple pattern, typically referring to subtle wave-like formations in blade geometry.
The outer side when the blade is thrust through the belt (for katana).
Blade worn thrust through the obi; katana or wakizashi in formal mounting.
Companion sword worn thrust through the obi alongside the main sword.
The inner side when the blade is thrust through the belt.
Primary side of the blade showing distinct hamon characteristics for identification.
Finger-like projections; small pointed extensions from the hamon into the ji area.
Fine wave pattern in the hamon resembling small, gentle ripples on water.
Scabbard; the sheath that holds the blade.
The curvature of a scabbard that matches the blade's curve for proper fit.

Scabbard inscription; attribution and description written on a shirasaya (storage scabbard) by a recognized expert. The authority of a sayagaki depends entirely on who wrote it. Inscriptions by Honma Kunzan or Tanobe Michihiro are highly valued, while those by less recognized individuals carry little weight. A sayagaki typically includes the smith attribution, blade characteristics, measurements, and date of examination.
Interlocking geometric pattern; continuous swastika-like design used on scabbard wrapping.
Blue ocean waves; decorative pattern of overlapping semicircular wave motifs.
Clear and cool; aesthetic term describing refined, elegant blade appearance.
Swords made in Seki province; blades produced by smiths from the Seki school tradition.
Soft metal spacers (typically copper) fitted into the nakago-ana of a tsuba to provide a snug fit to a specific blade's tang.
Attacking metal fittings; decorative metalwork on scabbards depicting aggressive or martial themes.
Reinforcing metal fittings that strengthen joints and stress points in sword mountings.
Pressure fitting; metal collar or ring used to secure components in sword mountings.
Pressure metal; reinforcing metal bands or fittings applied under tension or pressure.
File marks creating a thousand-step pattern, a decorative surface treatment on sword fittings.
Lengthwise file marks parallel to the tang.
Spacers placed on either side of the tsuba.
The platform or seat area on the tsuba where the seppa (spacers) rest against the guard.
Cutting or severing; refers to a blade's cutting ability or a break in the steel.
Cut signature; a mei (signature) that has been partially removed due to tang shortening.
Snow, moon, and flowers; classical decorative theme representing natural beauty.
Explanation; the descriptive text accompanying a sword evaluation.
Traditional Japanese unit of length equal to approximately 30.3 centimeters or one foot.
An alloy of copper and gold, patinated to a deep blue-black.
Crystalline formations in the steel; small, bright metallic inclusions in the blade.
Metal fitting used to secure or tension the cord wrapping on sword handles.
Metal fittings used for cord or rope pulling mechanisms in traditional Japanese equipment.
Wrinkled leather wrap used on sword handles, creating a textured grip surface.
Astringent quality; refers to a refined, understated aesthetic quality in sword appreciation.
Subtle elegance; refined, understated beauty that reveals itself through careful observation.
An alloy of copper and silver, patinated to grey.
Autumn rain file marks; a specific pattern of file marks on the nakago resembling rainfall.
Four gentlemen; decorative motif featuring plum, orchid, chrysanthemum, and bamboo.
Striped edge; a hamon pattern showing distinct parallel bands or stripes.
Island-like core pattern; irregular patches of hard steel within the hamon structure.
Island-like; describes isolated patches or island-like formations in hamon or hada.
Tightness or compactness; describes well-forged steel with good cohesion and density.
Tightening quality; well-controlled, compact steel structure showing discipline.
Tightening spirit; the quality of having a well-controlled, compact blade structure.
Tight; describes a compact, well-controlled hamon.
Stains or discoloration on the blade surface, often from age or improper storage.
True or formal; the highest level of formality in artistic styles and presentations.
True or straight file marks; parallel file strokes running perpendicular to the tang.
Bend; curvature caused by lateral stress.
Brass alloy used in sword fittings and decorative elements, composed of copper and zinc.
True essence or authentic quality; refers to the genuine characteristics of a blade.
Hidden hole; a concealed opening in sword fittings, often for practical purposes.
The ridge line running along the blade that divides the ji (flat) from the shinogi-ji.
Width of the shinogi ridge area; measurement from shinogi to mune.
Groove carved along the shinogi ridge line to reduce weight and add flexibility.
The flat area between the shinogi and the mune.
Base of the ridge line; area where the shinogi begins near the habaki.
The ridge line running along the blade's spine; the shinogi's linear profile.
The most common blade construction with a distinct ridge line (shinogi) running along the blade.
Bamboo-joint cut file marks; a specific pattern of horizontal file marks.
Examination or judging; the formal NBTHK process of evaluating swords for certification.
New-new sword; blades made approximately 1781-1868 (end of Edo period), characterized by revival of koto techniques.
Divine speed pattern; a type of decorative motif suggesting swift, divine movement.
Truly forged work; indicates authentic craftsmanship in traditional sword-making methods.
New sword; blades made from approximately 1596-1781, characterized by new forging methods after the unification of Japan.
Shintogo Kunimitsu; a Soshu smith who studied under Masamune. Known for fine tanto and wakizashi.
Tide or flow; refers to the natural movement or pattern in the steel grain.
Salt neck; a defect where the nakago shows corrosion or pitting from salt exposure.
Seven treasures inlay; decorative metalwork technique using multiple colored metals.
White appearance or pale coloration in steel, often indicating specific heat treatment.
Whitish appearance in the steel; a pale, cloudy quality in the metal structure.
Whitish, faint utsuri.
To become white or pale; describes areas of the blade that appear whitish due to polishing or metallurgical issues.
Plain wooden scabbard; undecorated storage mounting made of magnolia wood for blade preservation.
Buttocks or rear end; in sword terminology, refers to the bottom or tail end of components.
Plain wooden storage scabbard used to protect a blade when not in formal mounting.
White staining; discoloration or patina that appears as whitish marks on the blade.
White ray skin used for wrapping sword handles and scabbards.
Sunken relief carving.
A purple-tinged coloration that can appear in the steel of certain sword blades, often considered aesthetically desirable.
Lower cord; the braided cord used to secure the scabbard to the obi or belt.
Four Heavenly Kings; refers to four master swordsmiths of exceptional skill.
A Mino school descended from Soshu tradition via Kaneuji. Known for hitatsura and bold nie.
A sunken or subdued appearance in the hamon or steel grain pattern.
Subdued temper; a hamon with restrained, subtle activity in the steel.
Iris flower motif commonly used in sword decoration and seasonal themes.
Iris leather; leather with a pattern or texture resembling iris plant leaves.
Similar to shinogi-zukuri but without a yokote line, giving a continuous curve to the point.
First generation founder of a smithing lineage or school.
Small protruding form; a minor raised or projecting element in sword construction or fittings.
First transmission; early teachings or foundational techniques of a sword school.
Private estate system in medieval Japan that influenced sword production and ownership.
Flickering candle-like appearance in the hamon with small, dancing flame patterns.
Genuine work; an authentic blade confirmed to be by the smith whose signature it bears.
Small melon-shaped design, typically referring to tsuba or other fitting outlines.
Showa era (1926-1989); period designation used in sword dating and classification.

Red lacquer signature; attribution written in red lacquer, typically by Hon'ami appraisers during the Edo period. Applied to ubu (unshortened) nakago where gold inlay was not appropriate. Less permanent than kinzogan-mei but still a respected form of attribution when by a recognized authority.

Red lacquer attribution; post-Edo period variant of shu-mei. Unlike traditional shu-mei which was applied during the Edo period on ubu nakago, shu-sho refers to later attributions in red lacquer. Generally considered less authoritative than historical shu-mei.
Deputy military governor; historical title relevant to sword commissioning and ownership.
A temple name sometimes found inscribed on sword tangs, indicating religious dedication.
Master craftsman or head of a sword-making workshop or school.
Workshop or place of sword repair and restoration activities.
Main occupation or primary craft; refers to a swordsmith's principal profession.
Buddhist monk; often appears in sword maker names or signatures indicating religious status.
Complete set of sword mountings; all metal fittings for a particular koshirae.
Overall curvature; the total curve of a blade from tang to tip.
Rustic style; a simple, unpretentious aesthetic quality lacking refinement or sophistication.
Traditional transmission of techniques and knowledge passed down through generations within a school.
Traditional Bizen school style; refers to classical Bizen forging techniques and aesthetics.
Secondary groove; a smaller groove running parallel to the main hi (fuller).
Companion groove; a shorter groove alongside another.
Additional inscription on the tang, often added later to supplement the original signature.
Accompanying letter or certificate that provides attribution or authentication details.
Added signature; secondary inscription on nakago, often by later appraiser or owner.
Shaving or paring; refers to reduction of material through careful removal or cutting.
Complete set of metal fittings for sword mountings, including all hardware components.
Paired swords; matching set of two blades made as a coordinated pair.
Grass-foot style; a decorative pattern resembling grass or plant tendrils at the base.
Plain pattern; simple, undecorated design or surface without elaborate ornamentation.
School lineage or group of smiths sharing common techniques and stylistic characteristics.
Curvature or bend in a blade; the degree of curve from tang to tip.
The curvature of the blade.
A matched set of fittings.
Cursive script style of calligraphy used in informal inscriptions and signatures.
Sagami Province tradition; the Kamakura school.
Sagami Province sword school tradition known for notare hamon and distinctive tempering.
Swords made in the Sōshū school tradition, known for their distinctive hamon patterns and steel characteristics.
Plain copper.
Bamboo-blind pattern; vertical streaks in the hamon.
Bamboo-blind pattern; vertical streaks in the hamon resembling a rolled bamboo blind. Alternate form of sudare-ba.
Late Aoe school; the final period of the Aoe school of swordsmiths in Bitchu province.
Late Bizen school; swordsmiths from Bizen province during the late Kamakura to Muromachi periods.
Late period Seki school swordsmiths, referring to those working after the peak Muromachi era.
Late Sōshū school; the final period of the Sagami province sword school.
Late Sōshū school works; swords made in the declining period of the Sōshū tradition.
Ceramic-like patterns or textures appearing in the blade's surface treatment.
Inlay technique using contrasting metals; creates decorative patterns in sword fittings.
Overall shape and proportions of a blade; the fundamental form and silhouette.
Straight; the boshi runs straight to the point.
Straight or direct style; refers to a linear, undecorated approach in sword design or fittings.
Straight-hearted; a hamon that is predominantly straight with minimal undulation.
Straight insertion; a tang that enters the handle in a direct, linear manner.
Straight reflection pattern in the steel, appearing as parallel lines running along the blade.
Straight temper line; a hamon that runs in a relatively straight line along the blade.
Straight temper line running parallel to the edge.
Straight temper line tendency; primarily straight with slight variations.
Straight-hamon construction; a blade forged specifically to produce a straight temper line.
Straight hamon with small irregular variations; a subtle wavy pattern in the temper line.
Plain skin; steel surface with minimal visible grain pattern or forging marks.
A type of straight sword with fine, hair-like grain patterns resembling water streams.
Cross-hatched or intersecting file marks.
Streaked grain; steel texture showing distinct linear patterns running lengthwise.
Diagonal file marks.
Diagonal file marks; yasurime pattern running at an angle across the nakago surface.
Openwork; pierced or cut-through design.
Openwork carving; decorative grooves that pierce completely through the blade.
Openwork carving; decorative technique creating pierced or hollow patterns in metal.
Assistant or deputy; common element in smith names indicating rank or lineage.
Sukemasa crest; family mon associated with the Sukemasa lineage of swordsmiths.
Plain sword; simple sword carving without elaborate details.
Transparent emergence; subtle hamon activity that appears to emerge faintly from the steel.
Relief carving technique where the background is carved away, leaving raised designs.
Relief carving with openwork; raised carving combined with cut-through sections.
Remaining edge of a groove; the raised border left when carving horimono that doesn't reach the blade edge.
Charcoal-like grain pattern; dark, carbon-rich areas in the steel surface.
Charcoal-like grain pattern in the steel surface, appearing as dark streaks or patches.
Clear steel; describes exceptionally pure, clean-appearing steel with minimal visible grain structure.
Traditional Japanese unit of length equal to approximately 3.03 centimeters or 1.19 inches.
Extended length, longer than the standard for the blade type.
Shortened or compressed proportions, describing a blade that appears truncated.
Shortened length, shorter than the standard for the blade type.
Flowing sand; sweeping lines of nie in the hamon.
Sand-grain inlay technique using fine metal particles to create textured decorative surfaces.
Length extension; the process of lengthening a blade through careful forging and drawing.
Natural stretching spirit; describes the inherent flexibility and resilience in well-forged steel.
Dark reddish-brown lacquer color; named after Suo Province's traditional hue.
Shortened tang; the blade has been cut down.
Shortened signature; maker's inscription remaining after tang shortening or blade modification.
Pampas grass; decorative motif often found in horimono or tsuba designs.
Cricket pattern; a hamon with small, regular formations resembling cricket shapes.
A long sword worn edge-down, suspended from the belt. The primary battlefield sword of the Heian through Muromachi periods.
Tachi-style mountings for a suspended sword.
Tachi signature; a mei inscribed on the side facing outward when worn edge-down.
The front face of a tachi when worn edge-down; the side facing outward from the body.
The overall shape and proportions characteristic of a tachi sword, typically with greater curvature than katana.
The reverse side of a tachi when worn edge-down; typically the side without or with less elaborate decoration.
A Hizen Province school founded by Hashimoto Tadayoshi. Known for refined Shinto-era blades.
Engraving chisel or burin used for carving designs into metal surfaces.
Overall form, configuration, and bearing of a sword; the way its proportions, curvature, and physical characteristics present as a whole.
Thick flat construction; variant of hira-zukuri with increased thickness and no shinogi.
A systematic classification or organizational framework, often used in sword studies and cataloging.
Drum-shaped; refers to a rounded, barrel-like form in sword fittings or construction.
Drum-shaped metal fitting or ornament used in sword mountings.
Drum leather; thick hide used for covering drum surfaces, sometimes used in sword fittings.
Imperial treasures of Toyotomi Hideyoshi; swords from the collection of the Taikō ruler.
A Yamato school near Taima temple. Known for masame and robust construction.
High-footed ashi; tall vertical elements extending from the hamon into the blade body.
High-relief carving.
Raised sprinkled picture; maki-e built up in relief.
Hawk-feather pattern; V-shaped file marks.
Collection of treasures; decorative pattern featuring various auspicious objects and symbols.
Height or elevation; measurement term used for blade dimensions and proportions.
Bamboo shoot curvature; a blade shape with pronounced curve near the tang, resembling a bamboo shoot.
Woodpecker; refers to a pecking or dotted pattern resembling woodpecker marks.
Jewel or sphere; often refers to decorative elements or exceptional quality items.
Jewel dragon; a dragon depicted with or pursuing a sacred jewel (hoju).
Tamaoi school tradition, likely referring to a specific lineage of swordsmiths or martial arts.
A forging technique involving controlled hammering to create specific steel characteristics.
Cutting test inscription; record of test cuts inscribed on tang.
Test cutting; evaluating a blade's cutting ability.
Cod-roe belly; a nakago (tang) shape with a rounded, full contour on the ha (edge) side, resembling a belly full of fish roe.
Tanba Province; historical region known for sword production, modern-day Kyoto area.
A dagger or knife, typically under 30 cm in blade length.
Paper strip; a narrow authentication certificate or appraisal document.
A signature inscribed in a rectangular cartouche or panel format on the tang.
To fall over or collapse; describes a hamon that leans or tilts irregularly.
Graceful curve; refers to an elegant, flowing curvature in a blade's overall shape.
Hanging or drooping elements; refers to pendant decorative features on sword fittings or armor components.
A drooping or sagging quality in the blade's appearance or structure.
A slight bend or sag in the blade, often considered a defect affecting the sword's straightness.
Diagonal cord or sash pattern used as decorative motif on sword fittings.
Vertical orientation or standing position; refers to upright mounting or display.
Vertical oval shape; an upright elliptical form commonly used for tsuba design.
Vertical bamboo-leaf pattern in the hamon or grain structure running parallel to the blade edge.
Standing round shape; a tsuba form with vertical oval or circular outline.
Rice-bale shaped rivets; decorative fasteners used in sword mountings and armor.
Hand/style; refers to the distinctive working method or characteristics of a smith or school.
Hand-slanting file marks; diagonal yasurime created by hand pressure.
Hand-raised; improvement in a smith's skill level or the quality of their workmanship.
A Yamato school centered at Tegai temple in Nara. Known for masame and religious motifs.
Tegai school; a sword-making lineage from Yamato province known for distinctive hamon patterns.
Hand-engraved family crests or decorative patterns on sword fittings or blades.
Iron bone; refers to the core iron structure or framework within a blade's construction.
Canopy carving; a groove design resembling a ceremonial Buddhist canopy or umbrella.
Ceiling board or top plate, referring to the upper interior surface of a scabbard.
Typical work; a sword representative of a smith's or school's characteristic style.
Swords made during the Tenshō era (1573-1592), often characterized by specific construction and stylistic features.
Gunsmith; a metalworker who specialized in making firearms rather than swords.
Gun-related items; metalwork or fittings associated with firearms from the Edo period.
Iron fan; a folding fan with metal ribs used as a weapon or ceremonial item.
Iron ground; the base steel or iron foundation of a blade before hardening.
Iron elephant; a decorative motif or pattern featuring elephant imagery in ironwork.
Iron ground or base; the underlying iron foundation of a blade or fitting before treatment.
Iron and steel; general term for the metal materials used in Japanese sword construction.
Iron body; refers to the iron core or construction of a blade's steel composition.
Iron mountain master; specialist in iron ore extraction and preliminary steel production.
Sword diagram; detailed drawings or illustrations documenting a blade's features.
Scattered tempering; isolated patches of hardening above the hamon.
Famous Buddhist temple in Nara; historically significant for sword commissioning and preservation.
A pointed or sharp tip; refers to an extremely acute kissaki point.
Pointed boshi.
Pointed spirit; a sharp, pointed quality or character in the blade's appearance.
Pointed gunome pattern.
Pointed, angular peaks in the hamon.
Sharp-pointed feeling; describes a blade geometry with an acute, piercing point configuration.
Polish accumulation; areas where polishing compound or technique creates subtle variations in finish.
The stopping point in polishing; areas intentionally left unpolished for preservation.
Polish accumulation; areas where polishing compound has collected, often in grooves or depressions.
A polishing technique that reveals and enhances the hamon pattern by grinding away surface steel layers.
Burnished maki-e; design polished flush with lacquer.
Chinese hat-shaped guard or fitting; a conical umbrella-like form used in sword fittings.
Sword/blade; general term for Japanese swords.
Hood or cap; a covering piece, often referring to protective caps on sword components.
Especially worthy of preservation; NBTHK certification indicating superior quality above Hozon grade.
Especially Important; highest NBTHK designation.

Especially Precious; post-war NBTHK designation discontinued and discredited due to authentication scandals. Treat as equivalent to no papers—approximately 95% of attributions are unreliable. Exception: low-value fittings from inexpensive schools where modern Hozon certification costs exceed the value gained. Pre-1982 papers had green covers ('green papers' in Western collecting).
Original wooden storage box accompanying a sword or fitting; typically inscribed with attribution or provenance information.
Sword rack or stand; a wooden frame used for displaying or storing Japanese swords.
Turbulent wave pattern; irregular hamon resembling rough ocean waves.
Turbulent wave pattern; wild, irregular hamon resembling stormy ocean waves.
Captured edge; a hamon pattern that extends unusually high up the blade surface.
Handle or grip; general term for the holding portion of tools or weapons.
Shrine gate design; a carved motif representing the traditional Japanese gate found at Shinto shrines.
Even curvature along the entire blade length, like a torii gate.
Bird helmet; describes a curved, helmet-like shape resembling a bird's head profile.
Blade carvings; decorative or religious engravings made directly into the sword blade surface.
Swordsmith; master sword maker.
Collective term for all sword furniture and fittings including tsuba, menuki, and kozuka.
Swordsmith; craftsman who forges Japanese swords.
The sword guard.
Tsuba retainer; a small fitting that secures the hand guard in position on the tang.
Pot-lid shape; describes a rounded, dome-like form in various sword fittings.
Hammer marks; textured surface created by deliberate hammer strikes during forging.
Hammer-textured ground; a surface finish showing deliberate hammer marks for decoration.
The sixth year in the 60-year cyclical calendar system used for dating Japanese swords.
Joint or splice; repair technique where broken blade sections are welded together.
Joining metal; repair technique using metal patches to fix damaged blade areas.
Handle; the grip portion of the sword.
Handle wrapping cord; the braid wrapped over the same.
The area of the blade tang that extends into the handle; the portion covered by the tsuka.
Handle wrapping; the cord or silk binding wound around the tsuka in traditional patterns.
Handle curvature; the slight bend built into a sword handle for proper grip and balance.
Handle mouth; opening of the scabbard where the handle enters.
Handle mouth fitting; metal reinforcement at the scabbard's handle opening.
The wrapping technique or material used to bind the handle of a sword, typically silk cord or leather.
Wear, fatigue, or deterioration in sword fittings from age and use.
Worn or fatigued appearance in sword fittings due to age, use, or poor maintenance.
Attached stone; a polishing stone affixed to a handle for sword maintenance.
Accompanying items; accessories or fittings that come with a sword as a set.
An upward thrust or piercing motion; also refers to certain tang modifications.
Upward thrust feeling; the blade's balance and geometry optimized for thrusting attacks.
The overall forging and construction process of a blade, including shape and structural elements.
To make or forge; the act of creating a sword.
Contracted feeling; describes a blade with a compressed or shortened appearance in its proportions.
Compressed signature; inscription on the nakago written in a condensed or cramped style due to space limitations.
A compressed or shortened proportion in blade geometry, indicating areas where dimensions are reduced or condensed.
Claw or talon carving.
Clawed sword groove; a ken-hi carving with small projecting elements resembling claws.
Accumulation or buildup; refers to layered construction or accumulated elements.
Packed quality; dense, well-forged steel structure with tight grain.
To stack or layer; refers to the layering technique in sword construction.
Accumulation or layering; refers to built-up or stacked construction methods.
Rope or cord; may refer to twisted patterns in hamon or surface texture.
Packed or compressed; describes steel that is well-forged with tight, dense structure.
Angular or horn-shaped characters used in inscriptions on sword tangs.
Accompanying blade; a sword made as a companion piece to match another blade.
Parallel grooves; multiple hi (grooves) running alongside each other on the blade.
Sympathetic feeling or harmony between blade elements; aesthetic unity in sword design.
Parallel grooves; multiple hi (grooves) running alongside each other on the blade.
Paired grooves; two parallel hi (grooves) running along the blade surface.
Accompanied by or associated with; used to describe secondary features in sword analysis.
Crane and gourd motif; auspicious design symbolizing longevity and prosperity in sword fittings.
Crane leg side; irregular ashi extending into the hamon resembling crane legs.
A common name or popular designation used for a sword or smith, distinct from formal names.
Metal tube or cylindrical fitting used in sword mountings, often as reinforcement or decorative element.
Dew cord; decorative cord or string, often found on sword accessories.
Dew point; the tip or end portion of decorative cord elements.
U-crown; radical or character component shaped like an inverted U, used in inscriptions.
Original, unaltered tang; the blade has not been shortened.
An unaltered, original tang that has never been shortened or modified since forging.
Raised or embossed metalwork technique creating relief patterns on sword fittings.
Curved sword worn edge-up thrust through the sash (obi), the standard method of wearing katana from the Muromachi period onward.
Katana-style mountings for a thrust-through-belt sword.
Refolding or turning back the steel during forging; a smithing technique to refine the metal.
Folded-back edge; tang edge folded over during forging process.
Arc-shaped activities in the hamon; curved formations appearing along or within the temper line.
Reverse curvature where the edge curves inward, common on tanto.
Cormorant fishing items; decorative motifs or themes related to traditional fishing.
Right official school; a lineage or tradition of swordsmiths associated with official court positions.
Relief carving; design raised above the surface of the blade.
Plum blossom; popular decorative motif symbolizing perseverance and early spring in Japanese sword arts.
Plug; metal inserted to repair a flaw.
A Yamashiro family of metalworkers and sword makers active in Momoyama and Edo periods.
Cloud; pattern or design motif resembling clouds, often found in decorative elements.
A blade form with the shinogi line dropping sharply near the point, creating a cormorant-neck profile.
Cloud dragon; decorative motif combining dragon and cloud elements in sword ornamentation.
Fish motif design; decorative pattern featuring various types of fish used in sword fittings.
The back or inner side (facing the body when worn).
Reverse tile; the back or inner side of a curved metal fitting, often on scabbard hardware.
Reverse side silver/white metal; refers to contrasting metal treatment on sword fittings.
Back side tempering; hardened area visible on the reverse side of the blade.
The reverse or back side of a blade, opposite to the omote (front) side.
Reverse side or back surface, typically referring to the opposite face of an object.
Reverse tile; the back or underside surface of a tile-shaped component or decoration.
Moistness; a soft, subdued quality in the nioiguchi where the boundary between tempered and untempered steel appears blurred or hazy.
A moist, lustrous quality in the steel that suggests depth and vitality in the grain structure.
Shallow relief carving technique creating subtle raised designs on metal surfaces.
Downward-facing tendency; a blade curvature that appears to droop or face downward.
A misty, cloud-like reflection in the ji, especially characteristic of Bizen work.
The essence or spirit of utsuri; refers to the subtle reflection patterns in the steel.
Copy or reproduction; blade made in imitation of an earlier master's style.
Applied overlay; metal shapes soldered onto the surface.

Colloquial Western term for basic Kicho papers, which had a white cover. The lowest grade of the discredited Kicho system. Treat as equivalent to no papers—approximately 95% of attributions are unreliable. Exception: low-value fittings from inexpensive schools where modern Hozon certification costs exceed the value gained. See: kicho.
Harmony or balance in sword construction; the aesthetic unity of all elements.
Harmony spirit; concept of balanced spiritual and technical elements in sword making.
Classical Japanese poetry; sometimes inscribed on sword tangs or fittings.
Young forging; early work by a smith, typically showing less refined technique than mature pieces.
A short sword, typically 30-60 cm in blade length. Often paired with a katana as part of a daisho set.
Curved inward; describes an inward curving line or surface in blade geometry.
Bay-like curvature; a gentle, even curve along the blade's length resembling a bay.
Crack or split; a flaw in the blade where the steel has separated or fractured.
Fern-shoot shaped tang end, curving like an unfurling fern frond on early Japanese swords.
Split kōgai; two-piece hair pick that separates into chopstick-like implements.
Split signature; a maker's signature that spans across both sides of the nakago.
Cotton wrapping; padding or protective wrapping using cotton material.
Cotton wrapping; soft padding material used under tsuka-ito or other bindings.
Crossing wrap; a binding technique where cord or wire crosses over itself.
Crossing temper line; hamon that extends across the blade width in an irregular pattern.
Crossing wrap or spiral binding technique used on sword handles and scabbards.
Sharp blade; classification for swords with proven cutting ability based on historical test cutting records.
Excellent sharp blade; higher grade of cutting ability classification, indicating superior sharpness.
Supreme sharp blade; the highest cutting ability classification, reserved for blades of legendary sharpness.
Ring curvature; warping from heat or stress.
Arrow wound; a linear flaw or crack in the blade, often resembling damage from an arrow strike.
Break or tear; describes interruptions or breaks in hamon patterns or steel structure.
V-shaped groove or ridge, named after a mortar used for grinding medicine.
Arrow-quiver shaped bowl or container form in tsuba or other fittings.
Arrow-nock shaped; describes a V-shaped or notched profile, often referring to tang or fitting shapes.
Arrow feather pattern; decorative motif resembling fletching used in sword fittings and lacquerwork.
Arrow-notch shape; a V-shaped or forked configuration found in various sword fittings.
Arrow-notch temper line; a hamon pattern resembling the notched end of an arrow shaft.
Arrow-nock shape; a nakago-jiri (tang end) cut in the distinctive notched form of an arrow nock.
Burn damage; refers to heat damage or discoloration on a blade from fire.
The hardened edge or temper line; general term for heat treatment effects on the blade.
High temper line; refers to a hamon that extends unusually high up the blade surface.
The quality or result of the differential hardening process; how well the hamon turned out during tempering.
Downward extension of the hamon below the normal temper line.
High tempering; a hamon pattern that extends unusually high up the blade.
Heat treater; the craftsman responsible for the tempering and heat treatment of the blade.
The hardened edge area; the tempered portion of the blade.
The beginning of the hamon at the base of the blade.
The leading edge or front of the hamon pattern as it extends toward the spine.
The width of the tempered area (hamon).
Deep hardening that extends well into the blade's core, creating extensive hamon activity.
Deep hardening; heat treatment that penetrates deeply into the blade's core structure.
Heat damage or burn collapse; deterioration of the blade's temper due to excessive heat.
Dropped temper; area where the hamon (temper line) disappears or becomes unclear.
A flaw where the hamon (temper line) drops out or disappears completely in a section of the blade.
Freshly forged and tempered; a newly completed blade before final polishing and finishing.
Area where the hamon drops below the ha-machi.
Lowered tempering; a rehardening technique that moves the hamon line lower on the blade.
To lower or reduce the hardness of steel through controlled heating and cooling.
To temper or heat-treat steel at a lower temperature to reduce hardness.
Burn attachment; refers to how the hamon adheres to or burns into the blade surface.
Hardened area that extends to the very edge without visible hamon line.
Hardened core feeling; the internal hardened structure or tempered heart of the blade.
No turn-back; the hamon ends at the tip without returning.
Mountain cocoon; wild silkworm cocoons used for producing coarse silk thread.
Unrefined copper; mountain copper.
Mountain-shaped pattern or form, typically describing triangular configurations.
One of the five major sword schools of Japan, centered in Yamato Province (Nara), known for distinctive hamon and construction.
Yamato spirit; the characteristic essence and aesthetic of the Yamato school tradition.
A spear with various blade shapes.
File marks; deliberate filing patterns on the nakago for grip and identification.
File marks; the textured surface pattern created by filing on the nakago tang.
File marks on the tang.
Eight-lobed gourd shape; a decorative form with eight rounded projections used in tsuba and other fittings.
Leaves; leaf-shaped formations in the hamon.
Relief carving; raised design where the motif projects above the surface.
Dirt, stains, or surface contamination on a blade or fittings.
Horizontal or sideways orientation; used to describe lateral elements in sword construction or fittings.
Yokosuka designation; a classification or naming system associated with Yokosuka region.
The line separating the main blade from the kissaki.
Lion design by Yokoya school metalworkers; distinctive shishi motif style.
Armor-piercing dagger; a thick, sturdy tanto designed to penetrate armor joints.
Armor rings; circular patterns resembling chain mail links found in steel grain.
Armor-piercing blade; a thick, robust tanto designed to penetrate armor plates.
Night; may refer to dark areas in hamon or blade coloration patterns.
Good or excellent; a quality assessment term indicating superior workmanship.
Running water; isolated areas of nie in the ji above the hamon.
Archer's glove worn on the right hand to protect fingers when drawing a bowstring.
Superior work; a term indicating high quality craftsmanship in sword evaluation.
With signature; describes a blade bearing the maker's inscription or mark.
Signed blade; a sword bearing the smith's signature on the nakago.
Having a signature; refers to a blade bearing the smith's inscription on the tang.
A roughly cut or crudely finished tang end, often indicating field modification.
Complete signature; a nakago bearing the smith's full name and often additional information.
Inlay; embedding one metal into another.
Inlay technique using colored metals or materials to create decorative patterns.
Popular name; common or colloquial term used for a sword or smith, as opposed to formal names.
Bean striking; a term describing small, rounded impressions or markings on metal surfaces.
Miniature shrine hall; a carved design depicting a small Buddhist or Shinto shrine structure.
